html: 9.3.24  9:47 pm   hey mr. wurtz. i'm in my last year of high school and thinking about what degree i should pursue, for a forseeably big amount of my future life. i'm very idealistic and to balance this i try to frame my thoughts as logically as possible, which brought me to the conclusion that it would be wisest to choose something that has a "future" economically. however i think that i've reached the conclusion that All Jobs Are Equally Hard, which makes me think maybe the rightest answer to The Career Equation is to choose the best bridge to something you're truly passionate about. maybe that's why there are so many choices. therefore, i'll study illustration because i can't imagine not devoting as much time to Art as i possibly can. multimedia Art. fascinating. i say this because your Art inspired me deeply to follow this nagging feeling, and although i haven't been proven right just yet, i'm pretty thankful to you for helping me understand the value of simplicity in evaluating life and its little, actually pretty big quirks. anyway my question is this- Art is a means of survival in the sense that it anchors your sense of self and helps you stay consistent in your worldview even as it expands and builds upon itself, right- but does it ever stop feeling like if you don't obsessively materialize your thoughts you'll float away and lose your sense of identity? or is it that the more you immerse yourself in your Art and other means of Art, the more crucial it becomes for your survival?
original_html: 9.3.24  9:47 pm   hey mr. wurtz. i'm in my last year of high school and thinking about what degree i should pursue, for a forseeably big amount of my future life. i'm very idealistic and to balance this i try to frame my thoughts as logically as possible, which brought me to the conclusion that it would be wisest to choose something that has a "future" economically. however i think that i've reached the conclusion that All Jobs Are Equally Hard, which makes me think maybe the rightest answer to The Career Equation is to choose the best bridge to something you're truly passionate about. maybe that's why there are so many choices. therefore, i'll study illustration because i can't imagine not devoting as much time to Art as i possibly can. multimedia Art. fascinating. i say this because your Art inspired me deeply to follow this nagging feeling, and although i haven't been proven right just yet, i'm pretty thankful to you for helping me understand the value of simplicity in evaluating life and its little, actually pretty big quirks. anyway my question is this- Art is a means of survival in the sense that it anchors your sense of self and helps you stay consistent in your worldview even as it expands and builds upon itself, right- but does it ever stop feeling like if you don't obsessively materialize your thoughts you'll float away and lose your sense of identity? or is it that the more you immerse yourself in your Art and other means of Art, the more crucial it becomes for your survival?
